words.definition: A person who is learning at a school or college.
sentences: The **student** studied hard for the test.
Many **students** walk to school every day.
She is a new **student** in our class.

words.definition: A person who teaches, especially in a school.
sentences: Our **teacher** explains things very well.
The **teacher** helped me with my homework.
He wants to be a **teacher** when he grows up.

words.definition: A place where children learn.
sentences: I go to **school** five days a week.
The **school** has a big playground.
My brother started a new **school** this year.

words.definition: A group of students taught together.
sentences: Our **class** is learning about animals.
The art **class** is very creative.
How many students are in your **class**?

words.definition: A period of learning or teaching.
sentences: We had a math **lesson** this morning.
The music **lesson** was fun.
Always pay attention during your **lessons**.

words.definition: A set of written or printed pages bound together.
sentences: Read your **book** carefully.
I borrowed a **book** from the library.
This **book** has many colorful pictures.

words.definition: School work that students do at home.
sentences: Don't forget to do your **homework**.
I finished my math **homework** quickly.
My **homework** is about history.

words.definition: To spend time learning about a subject.
sentences: You need to **study** for your exam.
She likes to **study** in the quiet library.
We **study** English every day.

words.definition: To get new knowledge or skills.
sentences: Children **learn** new things every day.
I want to **learn** how to play the guitar.
It's fun to **learn** about different cultures.

words.definition: To look at and understand written words.
sentences: Can you **read** this story aloud?
I love to **read** before bedtime.
He is learning to **read** big words.

words.definition: To form letters or words on a surface.
sentences: Please **write** your name clearly.
She likes to **write** poems.
We **write** notes during the lesson.

words.definition: A tool used for writing with ink.
sentences: I need a **pen** to sign this paper.
My blue **pen** ran out of ink.
Can I borrow your **pen**?

words.definition: A tool used for writing or drawing, usually with lead.
sentences: Use a **pencil** for your drawing.
My **pencil** needs sharpening.
I always carry a **pencil** in my bag.

words.definition: A piece of rubber or plastic used to remove pencil marks.
sentences: I made a mistake, so I used my **eraser**.
This **eraser** works very well.
Do you have an **eraser** I can use?

words.definition: A book of blank pages for writing notes.
sentences: Write your ideas in your **notebook**.
I bought a new **notebook** for school.
She filled her **notebook** with drawings.

words.definition: A piece of furniture with a flat top, used for working or studying.
sentences: Put your books on the **desk**.
My **desk** is next to the window.
He sat at his **desk** to do homework.

words.definition: A piece of furniture for one person to sit on.
sentences: Sit down on the **chair**.
The **chair** is comfortable.
There are many **chairs** in the classroom.

words.definition: A dark board used for writing or drawing with chalk.
sentences: The teacher wrote on the **blackboard**.
We cleaned the **blackboard** after class.
The **blackboard** was covered with math problems.

words.definition: A white board used for writing or drawing with markers.
sentences: The teacher drew a diagram on the **whiteboard**.
We use a **whiteboard** in our meeting room.
Please erase the **whiteboard**.

words.definition: A soft white substance used for writing on a blackboard.
sentences: The teacher picked up a piece of **chalk**.
We drew pictures with colored **chalk**.
Don't make too much dust with the **chalk**.

words.definition: A pen with a broad felt tip, used for writing or drawing.
sentences: Use a blue **marker** for the title.
This **marker** smells like fruit.
Do you have a dry-erase **marker**?

words.definition: A bag carried on one's back, used for carrying books and other items.
sentences: My **backpack** is full of books.
He put his lunch in his **backpack**.
Always zip up your **backpack**.

words.definition: A special set of clothes worn by members of an organization or school.
sentences: All students wear a school **uniform**.
Her **uniform** is blue and white.
It's easy to get ready when you have a **uniform**.

words.definition: The head of a school.
sentences: The **principal** gave a speech this morning.
We met the new **principal** yesterday.
The **principal** is in charge of the school.

words.definition: A break between classes for students to play.
sentences: We play games during **recess**.
I look forward to **recess** every day.
The bell rang for **recess**.

words.definition: A place where books and other materials are kept for people to read or borrow.
sentences: I love to read in the school **library**.
The **library** has many interesting books.
Please be quiet in the **library**.

words.definition: A person who works in a library.
sentences: The **librarian** helped me find a book.
Ask the **librarian** if you need help.
The **librarian** organizes all the books.

words.definition: An electronic machine that stores and processes data.
sentences: We use a **computer** in the lab.
Learning to type on a **computer** is important.
My dad works on his **computer**.

words.definition: A global computer network providing information and communication.
sentences: We use the **internet** for research.
You can find many videos on the **internet**.
The **internet** connects people worldwide.

words.definition: To study a subject carefully to discover new information.
sentences: I need to **research** for my project.
We did some **research** about space.
Good **research** helps you learn more.

words.definition: A planned piece of work that has a specific purpose.
sentences: Our science **project** is about plants.
We worked on the **project** together.
The **project** is due next week.

words.definition: A talk giving information about something.
sentences: She gave a great **presentation** on dinosaurs.
We prepared a **presentation** for our class.
His **presentation** had many colorful slides.

words.definition: A formal test of a person's knowledge or ability.
sentences: I have a big math **exam** tomorrow.
Students need to prepare for the final **exam**.
The **exam** was very challenging.

words.definition: A short exam to check knowledge.
sentences: We had a spelling **test** today.
I hope I pass this **test**.
The teacher gave us a pop **test**.

words.definition: A mark indicating the quality of a student's work.
sentences: She got a good **grade** on her essay.
What **grade** did you get in science?
He works hard to get high **grades**.

words.definition: A report on a student's progress and grades.
sentences: My parents will see my **report card** soon.
I got all A's on my last **report card**.
The **report card** shows how well I am doing.

words.definition: The subjects taught in a school or college.
sentences: The school's **curriculum** includes art and music.
They are updating the science **curriculum**.
What is the **curriculum** for this year?

words.definition: An area of knowledge studied in school.
sentences: My favorite **subject** is history.
What **subject** are you learning now?
Math is a challenging **subject** for some.

words.definition: The study of the natural and physical world.
sentences: We do experiments in **science** class.
Learning about animals is part of **science**.
She loves to read **science** books.

words.definition: The study of numbers, quantities, and shapes.
sentences: I like solving problems in **math**.
Our **math** lesson today was about fractions.
He is very good at **math**.

words.definition: The language spoken in the UK, USA, and many other countries.
sentences: We read stories in **English** class.
Learning **English** helps you talk to more people.
My **English** teacher is very kind.

words.definition: The study of past events.
sentences: We learned about ancient Egypt in **history**.
My favorite part of **history** is learning about kings and queens.
He enjoys reading **history** books.

words.definition: The study of the Earth's physical features and human activity.
sentences: In **geography**, we learn about maps and countries.
We studied mountains and rivers in **geography** class.
She likes learning about different places in **geography**.

words.definition: The expression of human creative skill and imagination.
sentences: We painted pictures in **art** class.
She loves to draw and do **art**.
The school has a beautiful **art** room.

words.definition: Sounds arranged in a way that is pleasant or exciting.
sentences: We sing songs in **music** class.
Playing an instrument is a form of **music**.
She loves listening to classical **music**.

words.definition: Activities involving physical exertion and skill, often competitive.
sentences: We play many **sports** at school.
My favorite **sports** are soccer and basketball.
Being active in **sports** is good for health.

words.definition: A gathering of all the students and teachers in a school.
sentences: We have **assembly** every Monday morning.
The principal speaks at the school **assembly**.
During **assembly**, we sing songs.

words.definition: A device that makes a ringing sound, often used to signal class changes.
sentences: The school **bell** rings at the start of class.
The **bell** signals the end of the day.
When the **bell** rings, we go to recess.

words.definition: A room in a school where classes are taught.
sentences: Our **classroom** is on the second floor.
The **classroom** has many colorful posters.
We learn new things every day in the **classroom**.

words.definition: A room or building used for scientific research or experiments.
sentences: We do experiments in the science **lab**.
The computer **lab** has many new computers.
Be careful when you are in the **lab**.

words.definition: A scientific procedure to test a hypothesis or demonstrate a known fact.
sentences: We did a fun **experiment** with baking soda.
The science **experiment** showed how plants grow.
Safety is important when doing an **experiment**.

words.definition: A trip made by students to a place away from their school for educational purposes.
sentences: We went on a **field trip** to the museum.
The zoo **field trip** was exciting.
Our class is planning a **field trip** to the farm.

words.definition: Training people to obey rules or a code of behavior.
sentences: Good **discipline** helps everyone learn.
The teacher helps maintain **discipline** in class.
Self-**discipline** is important for studying.

words.definition: A statement that tells you what is allowed or required.
sentences: Follow the school **rules**.
The first **rule** is to listen to the teacher.
Breaking a **rule** can lead to consequences.

words.definition: The way someone acts or conducts themselves.
sentences: Good **behavior** is important in school.
His positive **behavior** was praised.
The teacher talked about appropriate **behavior**.

words.definition: A feeling of deep admiration for someone or something.
sentences: Show **respect** to your teachers and classmates.
We should always **respect** others' opinions.
Mutual **respect** makes the classroom a better place.

words.definition: A person whom one knows and with whom one has a bond of mutual affection.
sentences: My best **friend** sits next to me in class.
It's good to have many **friends** at school.
We help each other as **friends**.

words.definition: Tasks or projects done by several students together.
sentences: We did a fun **group work** activity today.
**Group work** helps us learn from each other.
Our **group work** project was about space.

words.definition: A sentence worded to elicit information.
sentences: If you have a **question**, raise your hand.
The teacher asked a difficult **question**.
Always ask **questions** if you don't understand.

words.definition: A reply to a question.
sentences: I knew the **answer** to the math problem.
Please write your **answer** clearly.
He gave the correct **answer**.

words.definition: To make something clear by describing it in more detail.
sentences: Can you **explain** this concept to me?
The teacher will **explain** the homework.
He tried to **explain** why he was late.

words.definition: To perceive the meaning of something.
sentences: Do you **understand** the lesson?
I need more time to **understand** this topic.
She quickly **understood** the instructions.

words.definition: Facts, information, and skills gained through experience or education.
sentences: Reading books helps you gain **knowledge**.
He has a lot of **knowledge** about science.
Sharing **knowledge** helps everyone learn.

words.definition: The ability to do something well.
sentences: Learning to code is a useful **skill**.
She has great artistic **skills**.
Practice helps you improve your **skills**.

words.definition: The process of finding solutions to difficult or complex issues.
sentences: Math helps us develop **problem-solving** skills.
We used teamwork for **problem-solving**.
Good **problem-solving** is important in life.

words.definition: The ability to remember information, experiences, and people.
sentences: I have a good **memory** for names.
Practice helps improve your **memory**.
He used flashcards to help his **memory**.

words.definition: To re-examine and make changes to something.
sentences: You should **revise** your notes before the test.
I need to **revise** my essay to make it better.
Let's **revise** the main points of the lesson.

words.definition: To do something repeatedly to improve one's skill.
sentences: You need to **practice** playing the piano every day.
**Practice** makes perfect.
We have soccer **practice** after school.

words.definition: To make or become better.
sentences: I want to **improve** my English speaking.
She worked hard to **improve** her grades.
Reading helps you **improve** your vocabulary.

words.definition: Forward or onward movement toward a destination.
sentences: The student made good **progress** in math.
We are seeing steady **progress** in the project.
Keep working, and you will make **progress**.

words.definition: To successfully bring about or reach (a desired objective or result) by effort, skill, or courage.
sentences: You can **achieve** your goals with hard work.
She hopes to **achieve** a high score on the exam.
We celebrated when we **achieved** our target.

words.definition: The object of a person's ambition or effort; an aim or desired result.
sentences: My **goal** is to learn a new language.
Set clear **goals** for your studies.
Working together helps us reach our **goals**.

words.definition: Physical or mental activity needed to achieve something.
sentences: Put in your best **effort** for the test.
His extra **effort** paid off.
It takes a lot of **effort** to learn something new.

words.definition: The reason or reasons for acting or behaving in a particular way.
sentences: Good teachers provide **motivation** to students.
His strong **motivation** helped him succeed.
Music can be a great source of **motivation**.

words.definition: To give support, confidence, or hope to someone.
sentences: Our teacher always **encourages** us to try our best.
Parents should **encourage** their children to read.
He felt **encouraged** by his friend's words.

words.definition: To give assistance to someone or something.
sentences: The school offers **support** to all students.
My family always **supports** my learning.
We need to **support** each other in class.

words.definition: To show or direct someone the way.
sentences: The teacher will **guide** us through the project.
A map can **guide** you to the right place.
He acts as a **guide** for new students.

words.definition: A book used as a standard work for the study of a particular subject.
sentences: Read chapter three in your **textbook**.
The science **textbook** has many diagrams.
We use a new **textbook** this year.

words.definition: A book containing exercises for students to complete.
sentences: Complete the exercises in your **workbook**.
The math **workbook** helps with practice.
She filled out her **workbook** carefully.

words.definition: A book or online resource that lists words and their meanings.
sentences: Look up the word in the **dictionary**.
A **dictionary** helps you understand new words.
Keep a **dictionary** on your desk.

words.definition: A book of maps.
sentences: We found the country in the **atlas**.
The **atlas** shows all the continents.
Use the **atlas** to learn about different places.

words.definition: A spherical model of the Earth.
sentences: The teacher pointed to a country on the **globe**.
A **globe** shows the Earth's shape.
We spun the **globe** to find places.

words.definition: A diagrammatic representation of an area of land or sea showing physical features.
sentences: We used a **map** to find our way.
Draw a **map** of your neighborhood.
The treasure **map** led to a secret spot.

words.definition: A small electronic device used for calculations.
sentences: Use a **calculator** for complex math problems.
I forgot my **calculator** for the test.
A **calculator** helps you check your answers.

words.definition: A straight strip of plastic, wood, or metal, used for measuring or drawing straight lines.
sentences: Draw a straight line with your **ruler**.
My **ruler** is 30 centimeters long.
Always use a **ruler** for accurate drawings.

words.definition: A tool used for cutting paper or fabric, consisting of two blades joined at a pivot.
sentences: Use **scissors** to cut the paper.
Be careful when using sharp **scissors**.
I need a pair of **scissors** for this craft.

words.definition: An adhesive substance used for sticking things together.
sentences: We used **glue** to stick the pictures.
This **glue** dries very quickly.
Don't get **glue** on your fingers.

words.definition: A stick of colored wax used for drawing or coloring.
sentences: Color the picture with your favorite **crayon**.
I have a box of many colored **crayons**.
The little boy drew with a red **crayon**.

words.definition: A colored liquid that is applied to a surface to give it color.
sentences: We used blue **paint** for the sky.
She loves to **paint** pictures.
Don't spill the **paint** on the floor.

words.definition: An implement with bristles, used for painting or cleaning.
sentences: Use a small **brush** for fine details.
Clean your **brush** after painting.
She dipped her **brush** in the paint.

words.definition: A container for carrying a packed lunch.
sentences: Don't forget your **lunchbox**.
My **lunchbox** has a sandwich and an apple.
He packed his **lunchbox** with healthy food.

words.definition: A container for holding water to drink.
sentences: Bring your **water bottle** to school.
My **water bottle** keeps water cold.
Remember to fill your **water bottle** before leaving.

words.definition: A person who trains a sports team or athlete.
sentences: Our soccer **coach** teaches us new skills.
The **coach** encouraged the team.
He is a very good basketball **coach**.

words.definition: A group of people working together.
sentences: Our school has a great basketball **team**.
We worked as a **team** to finish the project.
Being part of a **team** is fun.

words.definition: An event in which people compete against each other.
sentences: We won the school singing **competition**.
The math **competition** was challenging.
She loves friendly **competition**.

words.definition: Something given for achievement.
sentences: She received an **award** for her excellent grades.
The best student got a special **award**.
Winning an **award** feels great.

words.definition: A formal event held for a special occasion.
sentences: We had a graduation **ceremony**.
The awards **ceremony** was held in the hall.
The opening **ceremony** was very exciting.

words.definition: A person who offers to do something without being paid.
sentences: Many students **volunteer** at the local library.
She decided to **volunteer** for the school fair.
Being a **volunteer** helps the community.

words.definition: An organization for people with a common interest.
sentences: I joined the science **club** at school.
The art **club** meets every Friday.
There are many different **clubs** to join.

words.definition: A planned public or social occasion.
sentences: The school organized a sports **event**.
The annual book fair is a big **event**.
We are looking forward to the school **event**.

words.definition: A plan of activities or events and the times they are intended to happen.
sentences: Check your class **schedule** for tomorrow.
My daily **schedule** is very busy.
The teacher posted the new **schedule**.

words.definition: A list of times at which events are planned to happen.
sentences: The new **timetable** shows our classes.
Look at the **timetable** to see when lunch is.
Our school **timetable** changes each term.

words.definition: The latest time or date by which something should be completed.
sentences: The **deadline** for the project is Friday.
Don't miss the **deadline** for submitting your essay.
We worked hard to meet the **deadline**.

words.definition: Arriving or doing something at the agreed or proper time; on time.
sentences: It's important to be **punctual** for class.
She is always **punctual** for her appointments.
Being **punctual** shows respect for others' time.

words.definition: Not present in a place, at an event, or in a group.
sentences: He was **absent** from school yesterday.
Please let the teacher know if you are **absent**.
Many students were **absent** due to the flu.

words.definition: In a particular place.
sentences: All students were **present** in class today.
Are you **present** and ready to learn?
She marked the students who were **present**.

words.definition: The act of being present at a place or event.
sentences: Good **attendance** is important for learning.
The teacher takes **attendance** every morning.
Her perfect **attendance** record was impressive.

words.definition: Using superior strength or influence to intimidate someone, typically to force them to do what one wants.
sentences: The school has a strict policy against **bullying**.
It's important to report any **bullying** you see.
We learn how to prevent **bullying** in class.

words.definition: The condition of being protected from danger, risk, or injury.
sentences: School **safety** is a top priority.
Always follow **safety** rules in the lab.
Wear a helmet for your **safety** when cycling.

words.definition: The time or a period of time following the moment of speaking or writing; time to come.
sentences: Think about your **future** career.
Education prepares you for the **future**.
What do you want to be in the **future**?

words.definition: An occupation undertaken for a significant period of a person's life and with opportunities for progress.
sentences: She is thinking about her **career** options.
Learning new skills can help your **career**.
He chose a **career** in teaching.

words.definition: A paid position of regular employment.
sentences: My mom has a new **job**.
He is looking for a summer **job**.
What kind of **job** do you want when you grow up?

words.definition: A paid occupation, especially one that involves prolonged training and a formal qualification.
sentences: Teaching is a noble **profession**.
He chose law as his **profession**.
Many people enter the medical **profession**.

words.definition: A person's range of skills or abilities.
sentences: This course will expand your **skill set**.
A diverse **skill set** is valuable in many jobs.
He has a strong **skill set** in computer programming.

words.definition: An official record showing that you have completed a course of study or passed an exam.
sentences: A university degree is a valuable **qualification**.
What **qualifications** do you need for this job?
She has excellent academic **qualifications**.

words.definition: An academic title conferred by universities and colleges as an indication of the completion of a course of study.
sentences: He earned a bachelor's **degree** in science.
Getting a **degree** requires a lot of hard work.
She is studying for her master's **degree**.

words.definition: An educational institution or establishment, in particular one providing higher education or specialized professional or vocational training.
sentences: After high school, she plans to go to **college**.
Many students live in dorms at **college**.
He applied to several **colleges**.

words.definition: A high-level educational institution where students study for degrees and academic research is done.
sentences: She got into a good **university**.
He is studying engineering at the **university**.
Many famous scholars teach at this **university**.

words.definition: A teacher of the highest rank in a university or college.
sentences: The **professor** gave an interesting lecture.
She is a history **professor** at the university.
The **professor** answered all our questions.

words.definition: A series of lessons or lectures on a particular subject.
sentences: I am taking an online **course** in coding.
This **course** covers advanced mathematics.
She completed a short **course** on photography.

words.definition: The grounds and buildings of a university, college, or school.
sentences: The university **campus** is very beautiful.
We walked around the school **campus**.
The new building is on the north **campus**.

words.definition: A large bedroom for a number of people in a school or institution.
sentences: Many students live in the **dormitory**.
My friend shares a room in the **dormitory**.
Life in a **dormitory** can be fun.

words.definition: A restaurant in a school, college, or workplace where people serve themselves.
sentences: We eat lunch in the school **cafeteria**.
The **cafeteria** serves healthy meals.
Meet me in the **cafeteria** after class.

words.definition: The part of a theater, concert hall, or other public building in which the audience sits.
sentences: The school play was held in the **auditorium**.
The principal gave a speech in the **auditorium**.
The **auditorium** can seat many people.

words.definition: A room or building equipped for gymnastics, games, and other physical exercise.
sentences: We play basketball in the **gymnasium**.
The school **gymnasium** is very large.
Physical education classes are held in the **gymnasium**.

words.definition: An amount of money given by an organization to a student to help pay for their education.
sentences: She received a **scholarship** to study abroad.
He worked hard to earn a sports **scholarship**.
Many students apply for **scholarships**.

words.definition: The process or fact of entering a place or organization.
sentences: He got **admission** to his dream university.
The **admission** requirements are very strict.
We are waiting for the **admission** results.

words.definition: The act of officially joining a course, school, or college.
sentences: Student **enrollment** is open next month.
The school saw an increase in **enrollment** this year.
Complete your **enrollment** papers soon.

words.definition: The completion of a course of study at a university, college, or school.
sentences: My sister's **graduation** ceremony is in May.
We celebrated her high school **graduation**.
After **graduation**, he plans to travel.

words.definition: A certificate awarded by an educational establishment to show that someone has successfully completed a course of study.
sentences: He received his high school **diploma**.
The **diploma** is proof of your education.
She proudly displayed her **diploma** on the wall.

words.definition: An official document that states that a fact is true.
sentences: She earned a **certificate** in computer skills.
The swimming class gave us a participation **certificate**.
This **certificate** shows I completed the course.

words.definition: An educational talk to an audience, especially one given by a professor.
sentences: The professor gave a fascinating **lecture** on history.
Students took notes during the **lecture**.
His **lecture** covered many important topics.

words.definition: A period of instruction given by a university or college tutor to an individual or small group.
sentences: I have a math **tutorial** every Tuesday.
The online **tutorial** helped me understand the software.
Our small group meets for a weekly **tutorial**.

words.definition: A conference or meeting for discussion or training.
sentences: We attended a **seminar** on environmental issues.
The guest speaker led an interesting **seminar**.
Students presented their research at the **seminar**.

words.definition: A meeting at which a group of people engage in intensive discussion and activity on a particular subject or project.
sentences: I learned a lot at the writing **workshop**.
The school offered an art **workshop** for students.
We built robots in the engineering **workshop**.

words.definition: A task or piece of work allocated to someone as part of a job or course of study.
sentences: The teacher gave us a new **assignment**.
I need to finish my history **assignment** tonight.
This **assignment** requires a lot of reading.

words.definition: A short piece of writing on a particular subject.
sentences: Write an **essay** about your favorite animal.
Her **essay** received a high mark.
I spent hours writing this **essay**.

words.definition: A spoken or written account of something observed, heard, done, or investigated.
sentences: We have to write a science **report**.
The news **report** was about the school event.
Submit your book **report** by Friday.

words.definition: A brief statement or account of the main points of something.
sentences: Write a **summary** of the story.
The teacher asked for a short **summary** of the chapter.
His **summary** was clear and concise.

words.definition: A general description or plan giving the essential features but not the details.
sentences: First, create an **outline** for your essay.
The teacher provided an **outline** of the course.
Draw an **outline** of the human body.

words.definition: A preliminary version of a book, paper, or speech.
sentences: Write the first **draft** of your story.
The teacher reviewed my rough **draft**.
We need to revise this **draft** before submitting.

words.definition: To prepare written material for publication by correcting, condensing, or otherwise modifying it.
sentences: Please **edit** your essay for grammar mistakes.
She helped me **edit** my presentation.
It's important to **edit** your work carefully.

words.definition: To prepare and issue (a book, journal, piece of music, etc.) for public sale or distribution.
sentences: The students hope to **publish** their class newspaper.
He wants to **publish** his first novel.
The school magazine will **publish** our stories.

words.definition: A person of the same age, status, or ability as another.
sentences: Students often learn from their **peers**.
He asked his **peer** for help with the homework.
**Peer** review helps improve writing.

words.definition: A private teacher, typically one who teaches a single student or a very small group.
sentences: My math **tutor** helps me understand difficult concepts.
She hired a **tutor** to prepare for the exam.
The **tutor** explained the lesson clearly.

words.definition: The act of advising or training someone, especially a younger colleague.
sentences: The program offers **mentoring** for new students.
Good **mentoring** can guide you in your career.
She benefited greatly from her teacher's **mentoring**.

words.definition: A person trained to give guidance on personal or psychological problems.
sentences: The school **counselor** helps students with their problems.
You can talk to the **counselor** about your future plans.
The **counselor** gave good advice.

words.definition: A meeting between parents and a teacher to discuss a student's progress.
sentences: My parents attended the **parent-teacher meeting**.
We have a **parent-teacher meeting** next week.
The **parent-teacher meeting** is a good time to ask questions.

words.definition: Activities or subjects that are not part of the regular school curriculum.
sentences: Joining an **extracurricular** club is fun.
She participates in many **extracurricular** activities.
Sports are a popular **extracurricular** activity.

words.definition: An area of study or activity.
sentences: He is an expert in the **field** of science.
What **field** are you planning to study?
She wants to work in the medical **field**.

words.definition: The ability to read and write.
sentences: Early childhood education focuses on developing **literacy** skills.
Computer **literacy** is important in today's world.
The program aims to improve adult **literacy**.

words.definition: The ability to understand and work with numbers.
sentences: Developing good **numeracy** skills starts in primary school.
This game helps children improve their **numeracy**.
Basic **numeracy** is essential for everyday life.

words.definition: The evaluation or estimation of the nature, quality, or ability of someone or something.
sentences: The teacher uses various methods of student **assessment**.
We had a progress **assessment** at the end of the term.
The **assessment** helps identify learning needs.

words.definition: The making of a judgment about the amount, number, or value of something; assessment.
sentences: The school conducts an annual **evaluation** of its programs.
Student feedback is important for course **evaluation**.
The teacher's **evaluation** helped me improve.

words.definition: Information about reactions to a product, a person's performance of a task, etc., used as a basis for improvement.
sentences: The teacher gave me helpful **feedback** on my essay.
I always ask for **feedback** to improve my work.
Receiving positive **feedback** is encouraging.

words.definition: The act of teaching or guiding a student, especially individually.
sentences: She offers private **tutoring** in English.
**Tutoring** can help students who are struggling.
He provides online **tutoring** services.

words.definition: A person who is advised, trained, or guided by a mentor.
sentences: The mentor guided her **mentee** through the project.
As a **mentee**, she learned a lot from her senior.
The program pairs experienced professionals with young **mentees**.

words.definition: A person who provides instruction or education; a teacher.
sentences: She is a dedicated **educator** who cares about her students.
Good **educators** inspire their students to learn.
The conference was attended by many leading **educators**.

words.definition: The method and practice of teaching, especially as an academic subject or theoretical concept.
sentences: The new teaching method uses a modern **pedagogy**.
Effective **pedagogy** is crucial for student success.
She is studying different approaches to **pedagogy**.

words.definition: A brief account of a person's education, qualifications, and previous occupations, typically sent with a job application.
sentences: You need a strong **Curriculum Vitae** to apply for the job.
She updated her **CV** with her latest achievements.
Make sure your **Curriculum Vitae** highlights your skills.

words.definition: An official record of a student's academic performance.
sentences: You need to send your official **transcript** to the university.
My **transcript** shows all the courses I have taken.
Request a copy of your academic **transcript**.

words.definition: Former students of a school, college, or university.
sentences: The university held an event for its **alumni**.
Many successful **alumni** contribute to the school.
The **alumni** association helps connect former students.

words.definition: A long essay or dissertation involving personal research, written by a candidate for a university degree.
sentences: She is writing her master's **thesis** on climate change.
The **thesis** must be original and well-researched.
He defended his **thesis** successfully.

words.definition: A long essay on a particular subject, especially one written for a university degree or diploma.
sentences: His doctoral **dissertation** focused on ancient history.
Writing a **dissertation** requires extensive research.
She spent two years working on her **dissertation**.

words.definition: Relating to education and scholarship.
sentences: He has a strong **academic** background.
The university has high **academic** standards.
She excels in her **academic** studies.

words.definition: Relating to an occupation or employment.
sentences: He chose a **vocational** course to learn a trade.
**Vocational** training prepares students for specific jobs.
The school offers various **vocational** programs.

words.definition: Activities that are not part of the regular school curriculum, such as sports or clubs.
sentences: Joining **extracurricular activities** helps you make friends.
She is involved in many **extracurricular activities**.
These **extracurricular activities** build important skills.

words.definition: A course that students can choose to take, rather than having to take it.
sentences: I chose photography as my **elective** course.
Students can select two **electives** this semester.
The school offers a wide range of **elective** subjects.

words.definition: Required by law or a rule; obligatory.
sentences: Math is a **compulsory** subject in our school.
Attendance at the assembly is **compulsory**.
Wearing a uniform is **compulsory** for all students.

words.definition: A strong desire to know or learn something.
sentences: Her **curiosity** led her to explore new topics.
Encourage children's natural **curiosity**.
Science sparks many students' **curiosity**.

words.definition: An act of asking for information.
sentences: The student made an **inquiry** about the course schedule.
Learning through **inquiry** helps deep understanding.
We conducted an **inquiry** into the historical event.

words.definition: The act of finding something new.
sentences: Science is full of exciting **discoveries**.
Learning is a journey of **discovery**.
The new archaeological **discovery** was important.

words.definition: The introduction of new ideas, methods, or products.
sentences: The school encourages **innovation** in teaching.
Technology drives **innovation** in education.
His project showed great **innovation**.

words.definition: The objective analysis and evaluation of an issue in order to form a judgment.
sentences: Developing **critical thinking** skills is essential.
The debate helped us practice **critical thinking**.
Teachers encourage **critical thinking** in students.

words.definition: The action of working with someone to produce or create something.
sentences: Group projects require good **collaboration**.
International **collaboration** helps solve global problems.
Effective **collaboration** leads to better results.

words.definition: The state of being involved in something.
sentences: Student **engagement** is key to successful learning.
The teacher uses games to increase class **engagement**.
High **engagement** leads to better outcomes.

words.definition: The action of taking part in something.
sentences: Active **participation** is encouraged in class discussions.
Her **participation** in school events is excellent.
We value student **participation**.

words.definition: Ongoing assessments used to monitor student learning and provide feedback.
sentences: Quizzes are a form of **formative assessment**.
Teachers use **formative assessment** to adjust their teaching.
**Formative assessment** helps students improve during a course.

words.definition: Assessments that evaluate student learning at the end of an instructional unit.
sentences: Final exams are a type of **summative assessment**.
**Summative assessment** measures overall learning.
The project served as a **summative assessment** for the unit.

words.definition: A guide listing specific criteria for grading or scoring academic papers, projects, or tests.
sentences: The teacher provided a **rubric** for the essay.
Check the **rubric** to understand how your work will be graded.
A clear **rubric** helps students know what is expected.

words.definition: A collection of a student's work over a period of time, used to show progress and achievement.
sentences: Students keep their best artwork in a **portfolio**.
My writing **portfolio** shows my development as a writer.
The teacher reviews each student's **portfolio**.

words.definition: A teaching approach that tailors instruction to meet the individual needs of students.
sentences: The teacher uses **differentiated instruction** to help all learners.
**Differentiated instruction** allows for varied learning styles.
This method of **differentiated instruction** benefits diverse classrooms.

words.definition: The practice or policy of providing equal access to opportunities and resources for people who might otherwise be excluded.
sentences: The school promotes **inclusion** for students with special needs.
True **inclusion** means everyone feels welcome.
We aim for full **inclusion** in all school activities.

words.definition: Education for children with special needs, such as learning difficulties or physical disabilities.
sentences: She works in **special education** to support diverse learners.
The school has a dedicated **special education** department.
My brother receives **special education** services.

words.definition: A condition that causes difficulties in acquiring knowledge and skills to the level expected for those of the same age.
sentences: A **learning disability** can make reading challenging.
The school provides support for students with a **learning disability**.
Understanding a **learning disability** helps teachers adapt.

words.definition: Having exceptional natural ability or intelligence.
sentences: The school has programs for **gifted** students.
He is a **gifted** musician and a talented artist.
Identifying **gifted** children helps them reach their potential.

words.definition: The process of planning, reviewing, and implementing educational content.
sentences: The team is responsible for **curriculum development**.
Effective **curriculum development** meets student needs.
She specializes in early childhood **curriculum development**.

words.definition: A teacher's detailed description of the course of instruction for a class.
sentences: The teacher prepared a detailed **lesson plan** for the day.
A good **lesson plan** helps keep the class organized.
She adjusted her **lesson plan** based on student progress.

words.definition: Statements that describe what students will be able to do after completing a lesson or course.
sentences: The **learning objectives** were clearly stated at the start of the lesson.
Teachers design activities to meet specific **learning objectives**.
Understanding the **learning objectives** helps students focus.

words.definition: An approach to teaching that offers different ways for students to learn.
sentences: The teacher uses **differentiated learning** to cater to various student needs.
**Differentiated learning** ensures every student can succeed.
This strategy promotes personalized **differentiated learning**.

words.definition: An educational approach that combines online educational materials and opportunities for interaction with traditional place-based classroom methods.
sentences: Many universities now offer **blended learning** programs.
**Blended learning** gives students flexibility.
Our course uses a **blended learning** model.

words.definition: Learning conducted via electronic media, typically the Internet.
sentences: During the pandemic, **e-learning** became very common.
She completed an entire degree through **e-learning**.
Many resources are available for **e-learning** online.

words.definition: A course of study delivered over the internet.
sentences: I enrolled in an **online course** for graphic design.
Many universities offer free **online courses**.
Completing an **online course** requires self-discipline.

words.definition: An online learning environment where students and teachers interact.
sentences: We attend classes in a **virtual classroom**.
The **virtual classroom** allows students from different locations to learn together.
Our **virtual classroom** has interactive tools.

words.definition: An online seminar or presentation.
sentences: The expert hosted a **webinar** on educational technology.
I attended a free **webinar** about coding.
Many professional development sessions are now held as **webinars**.

words.definition: A digital audio file made available on the Internet for downloading to a computer or mobile device.
sentences: I listen to educational **podcasts** on my way to school.
This **podcast** explains complex science topics simply.
Teachers sometimes recommend relevant **podcasts**.

words.definition: The ability to find, evaluate, create, and communicate information using digital technologies.
sentences: Developing **digital literacy** is crucial for students today.
The school emphasizes **digital literacy** skills.
Good **digital literacy** helps you navigate the online world safely.

words.definition: An acronym for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics.
sentences: The school has a strong **STEM** program.
Many students are interested in **STEM** careers.
Promoting **STEM** education is important for the future.

words.definition: An acronym for Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics.
sentences: The school now includes arts in its **STEAM** initiatives.
**STEAM** education combines creativity with technical skills.
The new project is part of the school's **STEAM** focus.

words.definition: Learning by doing, rather than by just listening or reading.
sentences: We prefer **hands-on learning** in science class.
The workshop provided a great opportunity for **hands-on learning**.
Children benefit from **hands-on learning** experiences.

words.definition: Learning through experience, often involving reflection on that experience.
sentences: Field trips are a form of **experiential learning**.
The internship provided valuable **experiential learning**.
**Experiential learning** helps connect theory to practice.

words.definition: A teaching method in which complex real-world problems are used as the vehicle to promote student learning of concepts and principles.
sentences: Our science class uses a **problem-based learning** approach.
**Problem-based learning** encourages students to find solutions.
This method of **problem-based learning** is very engaging.

words.definition: A learning process that encourages students to ask questions, investigate, and discover answers.
sentences: The project promotes **inquiry-based learning**.
**Inquiry-based learning** helps students develop research skills.
Teachers often facilitate **inquiry-based learning** in their classrooms.

words.definition: An instructional strategy and a type of blended learning that reverses the traditional learning environment by delivering instructional content, often online, outside of the classroom.
sentences: In a **flipped classroom**, students watch lectures at home.
The **flipped classroom** model allows for more interactive class time.
Many teachers are experimenting with the **flipped classroom** approach.

words.definition: The application of game-design elements and game principles in non-game contexts, often to engage users.
sentences: The app uses **gamification** to make learning fun.
Teachers use **gamification** to motivate students.
**Gamification** can increase student participation.

words.definition: An educational approach that customizes learning for each student's strengths, needs, skills, and interests.
sentences: Technology enables more **personalized learning** experiences.
The school aims to provide **personalized learning** paths.
**Personalized learning** helps students learn at their own pace.

words.definition: An educational method that uses computers to adapt the presentation of educational material to the learning needs of individual students.
sentences: The software uses **adaptive learning** to adjust difficulty.
**Adaptive learning** systems can provide tailored feedback.
This platform offers an **adaptive learning** experience.

words.definition: Providing a remedy, especially for a deficiency or difficulty.
sentences: The school offers **remedial** classes for struggling students.
He received **remedial** support in reading.
**Remedial** education helps students catch up.

words.definition: The act of improving or enhancing the quality or value of something.
sentences: The school offers **enrichment** programs after class.
Reading books provides great intellectual **enrichment**.
Art and music add **enrichment** to our lives.

words.definition: The period of time when a school, college, or university is open and students are attending classes.
sentences: The new **academic year** starts in September.
We have a long break at the end of the **academic year**.
The **academic year** is divided into two semesters.

words.definition: A half-year term in a school or college.
sentences: This **semester**, I am taking five courses.
The fall **semester** begins in August.
We have exams at the end of each **semester**.

words.definition: A period of time during which a school, college, or university is open.
sentences: The school year is divided into three **terms**.
We have a holiday at the end of the first **term**.
This **term**, we are studying ancient civilizations.

words.definition: The fee for instruction at a school or college.
sentences: University **tuition** can be very expensive.
She received a scholarship to cover her **tuition**.
Many students work to pay for their **tuition**.

words.definition: A sum of money given by an organization for a particular purpose, especially education.
sentences: He applied for a government **grant** to fund his research.
The student received a generous **grant** for her studies.
Many foundations offer educational **grants**.

words.definition: A sum of money that is borrowed and expected to be paid back with interest.
sentences: Many students take out a student **loan** for college.
You need to repay your student **loan** after graduation.
He applied for a small **loan** to buy books.

words.definition: Money provided to students to help them pay for their education.
sentences: She qualified for **financial aid** to attend university.
Apply for **financial aid** early to get the best options.
The university offers various forms of **financial aid**.

words.definition: A period of time during which a student or trainee works in an organization, sometimes without pay, in order to gain experience.
sentences: He completed an **internship** at a tech company.
An **internship** provides valuable work experience.
She is looking for a summer **internship**.

words.definition: A system of training a new generation of practitioners of a trade or profession with on-the-job training and often some accompanying study.
sentences: He started an **apprenticeship** to become an electrician.
An **apprenticeship** combines learning with practical work.
Many trades offer great **apprenticeships**.

words.definition: The action or process of providing someone with an official document attesting to a status or level of achievement.
sentences: He received his teaching **certification** last year.
The program leads to professional **certification**.
This **certification** proves your skills in the field.

words.definition: The action or process of officially recognizing someone as having a particular status or being qualified to perform a particular activity.
sentences: The university received full **accreditation** for its engineering program.
**Accreditation** ensures quality in education.
Check for **accreditation** before choosing a college.

words.definition: The teaching staff of a university or college, or of one of its departments.
sentences: The **faculty** meeting is scheduled for Monday.
She joined the **faculty** as a new professor.
The **faculty** members are highly experienced.

words.definition: A specialized division of a large organization, such as a university or government.
sentences: He works in the history **department**.
The science **department** has new equipment.
She is the head of the English **department**.

words.definition: The head of a university faculty or department.
sentences: The **dean** of students welcomed the new students.
She met with the **dean** about her academic plans.
The **dean** oversees the entire faculty.

words.definition: The head of a university in some countries.
sentences: The **chancellor** presided over the graduation ceremony.
The university's **chancellor** announced new initiatives.
He holds the position of **chancellor** at the university.

words.definition: An official responsible for keeping records, especially at a college or university.
sentences: Contact the **registrar's** office for your academic records.
The **registrar** handles student enrollment.
She submitted her forms to the **registrar**.

words.definition: The department at a school or college that handles applications and admissions.
sentences: Send your application to the **admissions office**.
The **admissions office** provides information about applying.
I called the **admissions office** with a question.

words.definition: The office at a university or college that handles financial matters, such as tuition payments.
sentences: Pay your tuition fees at the **bursar's office**.
The **bursar's office** can help with payment plans.
I visited the **bursar's office** to discuss my bill.

words.definition: The department or services at a college or university that deal with the welfare and activities of students.
sentences: The office of **student affairs** helps with campus life.
She works in **student affairs** to support students.
Contact **student affairs** for housing information.

words.definition: A program of introduction for new students to a school or university.
sentences: New students attend an **orientation** session.
The **orientation** helped me learn about the campus.
We had a fun **orientation** day.

words.definition: A first-year student at a university, college, or high school.
sentences: He is a **freshman** in college this year.
The **freshman** class is very large.
As a **freshman**, she is still learning her way around.

words.definition: A second-year student at a university, college, or high school.
sentences: She is a **sophomore** and has more experience now.
The **sophomore** class is planning a fundraiser.
He is a **sophomore** in high school.

words.definition: A third-year student at a university, college, or high school.
sentences: He is a **junior** and thinking about his major.
The **junior** class is preparing for college applications.
She is a **junior** in high school this year.

words.definition: A fourth-year student at a university or college, or a final-year student at a high school.
sentences: She is a **senior** and will graduate soon.
The **senior** class is excited about prom.
He is a **senior** in college and looking for jobs.

words.definition: A university student who has not yet received a first degree.
sentences: She is an **undergraduate** student studying psychology.
The university offers many programs for **undergraduates**.
As an **undergraduate**, he is exploring different subjects.

words.definition: A student who has completed a first degree and is studying for a more advanced degree.
sentences: He is a **graduate student** working on his master's degree.
Many **graduate students** also work as teaching assistants.
She is a **graduate student** in the history department.

words.definition: A student who is studying for a degree or diploma after having already taken a first degree.
sentences: She is a **postgraduate** researcher in biology.
The university offers various **postgraduate** courses.
He decided to pursue **postgraduate** studies.

words.definition: The highest degree awarded by a university.
sentences: He is working on his **doctorate** in physics.
Earning a **doctorate** requires many years of study.
She hopes to complete her **doctorate** next year.

words.definition: A long academic essay based on original research.
sentences: I need to write a **research paper** for my history class.
His **research paper** was published in a journal.
Writing a good **research paper** takes time and effort.

words.definition: Evaluation of a person's work or performance by a group of people at the same level.
sentences: My essay went through a **peer review** process.
**Peer review** helps improve the quality of academic work.
The journal uses a strict **peer review** system.

words.definition: The commitment to and demonstration of honest and responsible scholarship.
sentences: The university has strict rules about **academic integrity**.
Plagiarism is a serious breach of **academic integrity**.
Students are expected to uphold **academic integrity**.

words.definition: The practice of taking someone else's work or ideas and passing them off as one's own.
sentences: Submitting copied work is considered **plagiarism**.
The teacher warned students about **plagiarism**.
Always cite your sources to avoid **plagiarism**.

words.definition: A quotation from or reference to a book, paper, or author, especially in a scholarly work.
sentences: Remember to include proper **citation** for all your sources.
Learning how to write a good **citation** is important.
The essay had many accurate **citations**.

words.definition: The action of mentioning or alluding to something.
sentences: Always provide a **reference** for information you use.
The bibliography lists all the **references**.
He made a quick **reference** to the textbook.

words.definition: A list of the books referred to in a scholarly work.
sentences: Include a **bibliography** at the end of your research paper.
The **bibliography** lists all the sources used.
She spent hours compiling the **bibliography**.

words.definition: A note at the bottom of a page, giving further information or a reference.
sentences: The author added a **footnote** to explain the term.
Check the **footnote** for the source of the quote.
Some academic papers use many **footnotes**.

words.definition: A note printed at the end of a book or section of a book, rather than at the bottom of the page.
sentences: All the references were listed in the **endnotes**.
The book included detailed **endnotes**.
You can find more information in the **endnote** section.

words.definition: A summary of the contents of a book, article, or speech.
sentences: Read the **abstract** to get an idea of the paper's content.
The conference program included an **abstract** for each presentation.
Write a concise **abstract** for your research.

words.definition: The action of introducing something.
sentences: The **introduction** of the book explains the main topic.
Start your essay with a strong **introduction**.
The teacher gave an **introduction** to the new unit.

words.definition: The end or finish of an event or process.
sentences: Write a strong **conclusion** to summarize your points.
The **conclusion** of the experiment was surprising.
In **conclusion**, education is very important.

words.definition: A reason or set of reasons given with the aim of persuading others that an action or idea is right or wrong.
sentences: Support your **argument** with evidence.
The student presented a strong **argument** in the debate.
His **argument** was well-reasoned.

words.definition: The available body of facts or information indicating whether a belief or proposition is true or valid.
sentences: Provide **evidence** to support your claims.
The scientist gathered **evidence** from the experiment.
There was not enough **evidence** to prove his point.

words.definition: A place, person, or thing from which something originates or can be obtained.
sentences: Cite your **sources** when writing a paper.
The library is a great **source** of information.
Always check the reliability of your **source**.

words.definition: An original document or firsthand account.
sentences: Letters and diaries are examples of **primary sources**.
Historians often rely on **primary sources** for research.
The old photograph was a valuable **primary source**.

words.definition: A document or recording that relates or discusses information originally presented elsewhere.
sentences: Textbooks and encyclopedias are often **secondary sources**.
She used a **secondary source** for background information.
Analyzing **secondary sources** helps to understand different perspectives.

words.definition: A thing that is known or proved to be true.
sentences: Always check your **facts** before writing.
It's a scientific **fact** that water boils at 100 degrees Celsius.
State the **facts** clearly and concisely.

words.definition: A view or judgment formed about something, not necessarily based on fact or knowledge.
sentences: Everyone has a right to their own **opinion**.
Distinguish between a **fact** and an **opinion**.
She shared her **opinion** during the class discussion.

words.definition: Prejudice in favor of or against one thing, person, or group compared with another, usually in a way considered to be unfair.
sentences: It's important to recognize **bias** in news reports.
Try to avoid **bias** when writing a research paper.
The survey results showed a clear **bias**.

words.definition: A particular attitude toward or way of regarding something; a point of view.
sentences: Try to understand different **perspectives** on the issue.
His unique **perspective** added value to the discussion.
The book offers a new **perspective** on history.

words.definition: A formal discussion on a particular topic in a public meeting or legislative assembly, in which opposing arguments are put forward.
sentences: Our class held a **debate** on environmental protection.
He is a strong speaker in a **debate**.
The students prepared arguments for the school **debate**.

words.definition: Conversation between two or more people as a feature of a book, play, or movie.
sentences: The play had interesting **dialogue**.
Effective **dialogue** is key to good communication.
We practiced reading the **dialogue** aloud.

words.definition: The action or process of talking about something in order to reach a decision or to exchange ideas.
sentences: We had a lively **discussion** in class today.
The teacher led a group **discussion**.
Open **discussion** helps everyone learn.

words.definition: A talk giving information about something.
sentences: She gave a great **presentation** on dinosaurs.
We prepared a **presentation** for our class.
His **presentation** had many colorful slides.

words.definition: The act or skill of speaking to a group of people.
sentences: Learning **public speaking** can boost your confidence.
She took a class to improve her **public speaking** skills.
Good **public speaking** is important for presentations.

words.definition: The combined action of a group of people, especially when effective and efficient.
sentences: Our project succeeded thanks to great **teamwork**.
**Teamwork** is essential for group assignments.
He values **teamwork** in all his projects.

words.definition: The process of working together to achieve the same goal.
sentences: We need good **cooperation** to finish this task.
International **cooperation** is vital for global issues.
The students showed excellent **cooperation**.

words.definition: The action of leading a group of people or an organization.
sentences: The school offers programs to develop student **leadership**.
Good **leadership** inspires others.
She demonstrated strong **leadership** skills.

words.definition: The state or fact of having a duty to deal with something or of having control over someone.
sentences: Taking notes is your **responsibility**.
He showed great **responsibility** by completing his tasks.
Learning to take **responsibility** is important.

words.definition: The fact or condition of being accountable; responsibility.
sentences: Students are held to high standards of **accountability**.
There is a need for greater **accountability** in education.
He takes full **accountability** for his actions.

words.definition: The quality of being honest and having strong moral principles.
sentences: Always act with **integrity** in your studies.
Her **integrity** is admired by everyone.
Maintaining **integrity** is crucial in all aspects of life.

words.definition: Moral principles that govern a person's behavior or the conducting of an activity.
sentences: The course covers professional **ethics**.
We discussed the **ethics** of scientific research.
Good **ethics** are important in all professions.

words.definition: A person's principles or standards of behavior; one's judgment of what is important in life.
sentences: The school teaches important moral **values**.
Family **values** are very important to her.
We discussed our core **values** in class.

words.definition: The status of being a citizen of a particular country.
sentences: The class learned about good **citizenship**.
He takes his role in global **citizenship** seriously.
Good **citizenship** involves respecting laws and others.

words.definition: A group of people living in the same place or having a particular characteristic in common.
sentences: The school is an important part of the local **community**.
We organized a clean-up event for the **community**.
Building a strong school **community** is vital.

words.definition: Understanding of global issues and interconnectedness.
sentences: The program aims to foster **global awareness** in students.
Developing **global awareness** helps us understand different cultures.
Reading news from around the world increases **global awareness**.

words.definition: The state of being diverse; variety.
sentences: Our school celebrates cultural **diversity**.
Embracing **diversity** enriches the learning environment.
The class has a lot of **diversity** in backgrounds.

words.definition: The quality of being fair and impartial.
sentences: The school strives for **equity** in education for all students.
Promoting **equity** ensures everyone has a fair chance.
We discussed the importance of **equity** in society.

words.definition: The practice or policy of providing equal access to opportunities and resources for people who might otherwise be excluded.
sentences: The school promotes **inclusion** for students with special needs.
True **inclusion** means everyone feels welcome.
We aim for full **inclusion** in all school activities.

words.definition: The state of being comfortable, healthy, or happy.
sentences: The school focuses on student **well-being**.
Mental **well-being** is as important as physical health.
Activities that promote **well-being** are encouraged.

words.definition: The established set of attitudes held by someone.
sentences: Having a growth **mindset** helps you learn from mistakes.
Her positive **mindset** helped her overcome challenges.
Develop a curious **mindset** for learning.

words.definition: The capacity to recover quickly from difficulties; toughness.
sentences: Building **resilience** helps students face challenges.
Her **resilience** allowed her to bounce back after failure.
Education helps foster **resilience**.

words.definition: Persistence in doing something despite difficulty or delay in achieving success.
sentences: Success often comes through hard work and **perseverance**.
His **perseverance** helped him master the difficult skill.
Keep practicing with **perseverance**.

words.definition: The quality of being able to adjust to new conditions.
sentences: Developing **adaptability** is crucial in a changing world.
Students need **adaptability** to succeed in different environments.
Her high **adaptability** made her a quick learner.

words.definition: The introduction of new ideas, methods, or products.
sentences: The school encourages **innovation** in teaching.
Technology drives **innovation** in education.
His project showed great **innovation**.

words.definition: The use of imagination or original ideas to create something.
sentences: Art class encourages **creativity**.
Her project showed a lot of **creativity**.
Think with **creativity** to solve problems.

words.definition: The responsible use of technology by anyone who uses computers, the Internet, and digital devices to engage with society.
sentences: Learning about **digital citizenship** keeps you safe online.
The school teaches students about good **digital citizenship**.
Practicing **digital citizenship** means being respectful online.

words.definition: The ongoing, voluntary, and self-motivated pursuit of knowledge for personal or professional reasons.
sentences: Education is a journey of **lifelong learning**.
Embrace **lifelong learning** to stay curious.
Many professionals engage in **lifelong learning** to update skills.
